awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: RUI: THE INFLUENCE OF MANGROVE INVASION AND RISING TEMPERATURES ON BELOWGROUND PROCESSES IN COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS
awd_abstract_narration:
The marshes and mangroves that line our coasts protect human populations from large storms and provide recreational activities for millions of people. The very existence of these coastal ecosystems depends on their ability to gain soil to keep pace with rising seas. Wetland plant root growth pushes the soil surface upward relative to the ocean, but not all plants do this in the same way. Large areas of southeastern US coastal wetlands have converted from grassy marshes to woody mangrove forests as temperatures have increased over the past decades, possibly enhancing the capacity of these ecosystems to resist storms and build soil.  Using experiments that simulate future ecosystems, the team of scientists will investigate how Florida wetlands, both marshes and mangroves, will continue to protect people as both temperatures and seas continue to rise. They will use their results to perform an economic assessment of these changing coastal ecosystems at three Florida reserves used heavily by the public. In addition to advancing understanding of coastal ecosystem responses to varying climate, results from their assessment will be used to 1) inform federal, state and local land managers about the changing coastal protection value of their lands and 2) educate visitors about these special coastal landscapes.

Mangrove invasion could change the nature of root inputs and potentially alter soil elevation. Warming could also accelerate microbial decomposition of organic matter and thus decrease or reverse soil accumulation, which could put wetlands at risk in the face of rising seas. The research team will address the question: How do warming and mangrove invasion into salt marshes alter root productivity and organic matter decomposition, mechanisms that control coastal wetland viability? Using six existing research sites along the East Coast of FL, passive warming chambers and mesocosm experiments, the investigators propose to examine the countervailing influences of rising temperatures and plant invasion on soil elevation gain. The team will conduct warming experiments at each of three FL coastal wetland sites, which will be some of the first warming experiments in tropical and subtropical climates, thus filling a major gap in scientific knowledge. In order to assess how a variable climate and mangrove invasion will alter the coastal protection capacity of FL wetland ecosystems, the investigators will perform a natural capital assessment at these sites using the InVEST software developed by the Natural Capital Project. They will use this ecosystem service assessment to develop a 3D video informing visitors to these reserves of how their public lands are changing.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: VILLANOVA UNIVERSITY IN THE STATE OF PENNSYLVANIA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Mangroves are encroaching into salt marshes around the world and this plant shift could change how coastal wetlands keep up with sea level rise. Using a series of passive warming experiments, we were able to learn about how mangrove and salt marsh wetlands build surface elevation to maintain their position against rising seas and big storms.   We found that mangroves respond to warmer temperatures by growing more in the northern-most site we studied. Using a model that explores various future sea levels, we discovered mangroves build surface elevation four times more rapidly than salt marshes do (40 and 60cm in 100 years) but that they collapse more quickly under the highest rates of sea level rise (100cm). Communities of microbenthic algae and meiofauna differ between mangrove and salt marsh dominated sites, suggesting that food webs may differ between these dominant wetland plant types. Taken together these and our other findings suggest that the encroachment of mangroves into salt marshes may create a diverse matrix of habitats that may provide some resilience to rising sea levels. However, extreme freeze events that have killed mangroves elsewhere could disrupt these diverse coastal wetland ecotones.

With this NSF support, we were able to publish ten manuscripts and have 20 engagements with various media sources to help communicate this work. As a team of five institutions, we also trained 24 undergraduate researchers, ten graduate students and one postdoctoral fellow through collaborative work in the field, lab and greenhouse. Through the development of a spatially-explicit coastal vulnerability model for Northeast Florida and two workshops with local land stewards, we have been able to build a team of people working together on coastal wetland restoration and conservation in the Guana Tolomato Matanzas National Estuarine Research Reserve (GTMNERR), which houses our sites. With our partners at the GTMNERR, we created a virtual tour of our field sites which has been used in the St. John’s County schools and was particularly important during online learning. The environmental education center at GTMNERR also features coastal wetland programming developed from our WETFEET project and citizen scientists associated with the GTMNERR have been integral in gathering data for our efforts. The findings and infrastructure developed from the first iteration of the NSF-funded WETFEET project have led us to new explorations of how excess nutrients are impacting these special and important wetlands that line our nation’s coasts.  

 


Last Modified: 05/31/2023
Modified by: Samantha K Chapman
